title-group.article-title: An Adolescent With Pseudomigraine, Transient Headache, Neurological Deficits, and Lymphocytic Pleocytosis (HaNDL Syndrome)
title-group.subtitle: Case Report and Review of the Literature

article-meta.aff: 1The Children’s Hospital at Saint Peter’s University Hospital, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
2University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
3Drexel University College of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Robert W. Tolan Jr, The Children’s Hospital at Saint Peter’s University Hospital, MOB 3110, 254 Easton Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ 08901, USA. Email: rtolan@saintpetersuh.com

abstract.p: We report a 16-year-old adolescent with 2 episodes of focal neurological deficits, pseudomigrainous headache, and lymphocytic pleocytosis due to the syndrome of transient headache and neurological deficits with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) lymphocytosis (HaNDL), also known as pseudomigraine with CSF pleocytosis. Review of the literature identifies 13 additional cases of HaNDL in the pediatric population. These cases are reviewed and evidence for possible etiopathogenesis is discussed. This syndrome may mimic much more common conditions such as complicated or hemiplegic migraine, aseptic meningitis, meningoencephalitis, or stroke. However, HaNDL differs from complicated or hemiplegic migraine and stroke since CSF pleocytosis is uniformly present. There are many infectious conditions that can present with neurological deficits, headache, and CSF pleocytosis, but the transient nature of the deficits and lack of a consistently identifiable infectious etiology despite extensive evaluations typify HaNDL. This clinical syndrome is underrecognized and underreported. HaNDL remains a diagnosis of exclusion.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The syndrome of transient headache and neurologic deficits with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) lymphocytosis (HaNDL), also known as pseudomigraine with CSF pleocytosis, was first described in 1981.1 HaNDL syndrome is a benign condition characterized by one or more episodes of severe headache, transient neurologic deficits, and CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis. The most frequent neurologic signs are hemiparesis, hemisensory disturbances, and aphasia.

HaNDL is included in the second edition of the International Classification of Headache Disorders2 and is classified as a “headache attributed to nonvascular intracranial disorder.” The diagnostic criteria include (a) episodes of moderate or severe headache lasting hours before resolving fully; (b) CSF pleocytosis with lymphocytic predominance (>15 cells/mm3), normal neuroimaging, and negative CSF culture and other tests for etiology; (c) episodes of headache are accompanied by or shortly follow transient neurologic deficits, and commence in close temporal relation to the development of CSF pleocytosis; and (d) episodes of headache and neurologic deficits recur over fewer than 3 months.2 The distinguishing feature of HaNDL is CSF pleocytosis, as seen in a series of adult patients with HaNDL who had typical lymphocytic predominance and elevated opening pressure, ranging from 10 to 40 cm (mean 23 cm).3

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 16-year-old male adolescent developed several hours of confusion, decreased use of the right arm, and right-sided facial weakness. Past medical history was significant for 3 to 4 headaches a month, associated with photophobia, phonophobia, and vomiting. Family history was also notable for migraine headaches in the mother and the maternal aunt.

On the day of initial evaluation he had a headache, mild photophobia, right arm weakness, and right facial weakness. He was confused and his speech was difficult to comprehend. In the emergency department, his weakness gradually improved, but he remained confused and began vomiting. Physical examination revealed inability to perform simple multiplication or subtraction, difficulty writing a sentence, and difficulty answering simple questions. Repeat physical examination within several hours was unremarkable, however. Laboratory evaluation included a white blood cell (WBC) count of 9.6/mm3 with 47% neutrophils, 42% lymphocytes, 7% monocytes, and 4% eosinophils. C-reactive protein was less than 5 mg/L and comprehensive metabolic panel was within normal limits. Imaging included a noncontrast computed tomographic scan of the brain (normal) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that demonstrated increased signal in the cortical sulci, right greater than left, in the fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) sequences (Figure 1). Ten-hour video electroencephalography (EEG) revealed no abnormality. A diagnosis of complex migraine headache was made and he received symptomatic treatment. His symptoms lasted approximately 12 hours and he was discharged home on topiramate for migraine prophylaxis.

caption.p: Magnetic resonance imaging FLAIR (fluid attenuated inversion recovery) sequence demonstrating increased signal in the sulci, right greater than left.

sec.p: He was readmitted 4 days later with severe headache, one episode of vomiting, right-sided weakness, confusion, and aphasia. Physical examination revealed a combative patient not responding to questions and instructions. He was not able to recognize his parents. There was no nuchal rigidity and Kernig and Brudzinski signs were negative. The rest of the neurologic examination showed no focality.

Cerebrospinal fluid studies obtained under sedation revealed 110 WBC with 98% lymphocytes and 2% monocytes, glucose 59 mg/dL, protein 83 mg/dL, opening pressure 38 cm, and closing pressure 16 cm. He was admitted to the intensive care unit with a diagnosis of meningoencephalitis and treated with acyclovir, ceftriaxone, and vancomycin. Additional studies included a peripheral WBC count of 10.7/mm3 with 67% neutrophils, 25% lymphocytes, 6% monocytes, and 2% eosinophils. Comprehensive metabolic panel and ammonia were within normal limits. CSF polymerase chain reaction assays for herpes simplex virus (HSV), enterovirus, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis were negative. Tuberculin skin testing and interferon gamma release assay were negative. India ink examination showed no encapsulated organisms. Human immunodeficiency virus, West Nile virus, Epstein–Barr virus, Lyme, and Bartonella serologies were negative. Rheumatoid factor, antinuclear antibody, and Sjögren’s serologies were negative as well. Video EEG demonstrated left hemispheric slowing but no ictal or interictal epileptiform activity. MRI of the brain revealed increased signal along the cortical sulci in the postcontrast FLAIR sequence, slightly improved from the prior study. Magnetic resonance angiography of the brain and neck was unremarkable. His mental status markedly improved within 6 hours. The right-sided weakness and aphasia gradually resolved and he returned to normal within hours of onset, although he had intermittent headache for several days. Final bacterial, viral, and fungal cultures of CSF were negative. At follow-up, he continued to have baseline migraine symptoms.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Review of the literature reveals 13 cases of HaNDL in the pediatric population.1,4-10 These cases and our case are summarized in Table 1. The subjects were aged 7, 7, 10, 13, 14, 14, 15, 16, 16, 16, 16, 16, 17, and 17 years (mean 14 years) and 10 (71%) were female. Eleven subjects experienced more than 1 attack (ranging from 1 to 8). Six of 13 (46%) subjects had a personal and family history of migraine headache (not reported for 1 subject). Seven of 14 (50%) subjects experienced episodes of confusion and lethargy. Only 1 had fever during the course of illness and 2 of 14 (14%) subjects had preceding viral-like illness. The neurological signs often included unilateral weakness and aphasia, which were accompanied by confusion and speech disturbances. All focal neurological signs and symptoms were transient.

caption.p: Clinical, Laboratory, and Other Findings in Pediatric HaNDL Patients.

fn.p: Abbreviations: F, female; M, male; CSF, cerebrospinal fluid; OP, opening pressure; WBC, white blood cell; EEG, electroencephalogram; CT, computed tomography; WNL, within normal limits; HA, headache; N/R, not reported; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; MRA, magnetic resonance angiography; HSV, herpes simplex virus; PCR, polymerase chain reaction; EBV, Epstein–Barr virus; TB, tuberculosis; HIV, human immunodeficiency virus.

sec.p: Cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities included predominantly mononuclear pleocytosis with 12 to 327 WBC/mm3 (median 80 WBC/mm3; mean 102 WBC/mm3) and between 10% and 100% mononuclear cells (median 100%; mean 93%). Seven reported CSF opening pressure ranged from 10 to 38 cm (median 27 cm; mean 25 cm). The CSF protein was reported in 10 of the cases, ranging from 30 to 151 mg/dL (median 75 mg/dL; mean 67 mg/dL). CSF glucose levels were normal. Imaging studies were remarkable for normal computed tomographic scans of the brain in 11 of 11 subjects. One subject had a normal MRI of the brain; our patient’s MRI was minimally abnormal. Magnetic resonance angiography results in 2 cases were unremarkable. The 3 EEG studies reported demonstrated only nonspecific slowing.1,9,10

Infectious etiologies were pursued and reported for 5 subjects; only one was found to have echovirus meningitis.5 Otherwise, when bacterial, fungal, and/or virus cultures were performed, the results were negative. Alternate causes excluded were California encephalitis virus, St Louis encephalitis virus, Epstein–Barr virus, human immunodeficiency virus, West Nile virus, Western encephalitis virus, mumps virus, HSV, enteroviruses, tuberculosis, syphilis, Lyme, Bartonella, and Mycoplasma.1,7,9,10

The etiology of HaNDL is unknown but is suspected to be migrainous or infectious. Among adults with HaNDL, brain single-photon emission computed tomography studies have demonstrated areas of decreased blood flow on the side of origin of the neurological deficits (which corresponds to the areas of focal slowing on EEG). These findings suggest a migrainous origin of HaNDL, with focal impaired neuronal metabolism and hypoperfusion.11 The symmetrical fluctuations in velocity of cerebral arterial blood flow observed in transcranial doppler studies also suggest that intracranial vasomotor changes play a role in the pathophysiology of HaNDL, perhaps triggered by a viral or other infection.12

A 16-year-old female with HaNDL syndrome was found to have cortical excitability changes with quantal release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.9 These findings suggest that HaNDL could be a form of migraine due to a channelopathy.9 This hypothesis is also supported by similarities between familial hemiplegic migraine and HaNDL.13 However, genetic analysis of patients with HaNDL have not identified mutations in the familial hemiplegic migraine gene, CACNA1A.14

Recurrent pleocytosis raises the diagnostic possibility of HSV (Mollaret’s) meningitis, which presents with episodic mild fever, photophobia, headache, and change in mental status.15 Characteristic CSF findings include marked pleocytosis with neutrophils, lymphocytes, and large mononuclear (Mollaret) cells that are typical for this disease, but not for HaNDL. Phenotypically, Mollaret’s cells have bean-shaped nuclei and deep nuclear clefts.15 Furthermore, typical Mollaret cells were not present in a 10-year-old girl with HaNDL.10

An 18-year-old female with HaNDL syndrome was thought to be infected with human herpesvirus-6 on the basis of elevated immunoglobulin M levels that normalized over a period of 4 weeks.16 Brain MRI demonstrated diffuse gadolinium enhancement at the time of acute aphasia and right-sided motor and sensory deficits. EEG showed slow waves in the left temporo-parieto-occipital region followed by diffuse bilateral slowing.

It has been hypothesized that HaNDL is a result of immune-mediated mechanisms following a viral infection,3,16-18 leading to subsequent production of antibodies to neuronal and/or cerebral vascular tissue.17 This mechanism may be similar to a described phenomenon in which 10% of patients develop headache following administration of high-dose immune globulin intravenous. Transient focal deficits may also occur. This complication has been explained by complex interactions between immunoglobulin alloantibodies and endothelial antigens in cerebral vessels.19 Viruses may play a similar role in the pathogenesis of HaNDL.

Although HaNDL is a self-limiting condition, it is part of a large differential diagnosis. This syndrome may mimic much more common conditions such as complicated or hemiplegic migraine, aseptic meningitis, meningoencephalitis, and stroke. Exclusion of infectious causes and acute cerebrovascular insult such as ischemic stroke is essential for diagnosing HaNDL syndrome. Rare in pediatrics, stroke remains a very important condition that must be excluded because of the limited time window for thrombolysis. Thrombolytic therapy has been considered in patients with HaNDL syndrome mimicking an acute stroke.20,21 Diffusion-weighted MRI is highly accurate in acute ischemic stroke of less than 6 hours’ duration and recommended when differentiating stroke from HaNDL.22

Despite thorough evaluation for infectious etiologies of HaNDL in both children and adults, its possible infectious origin remains to be identified.1,3,5-10,12 There are many infectious conditions that can present with neurological deficits, headache, and CSF pleocytosis, but the transient nature of the deficits and lack of consistently discoverable etiology despite extensive evaluations typify HaNDL. This clinical syndrome is underrecognized and underreported. HaNDL remains a diagnosis of exclusion.

ack.p: The authors thank Dr Carlos Lastra for thoughtful review of the article and Jeannine Creazzo and Elizabeth Herron of the Saint Peter’s University Hospital Library for assistance with review of the literature.
